natural problem: There are two cameras that take pictures of a traffic intersection. Camera A starts taking pictures at $6$ AM and takes a picture every $11$ minutes. Camera B starts taking pictures at $7$ AM and takes pictures every $7$ minutes. Camera A and Camera B take a picture at the same time at four different times before noon. When Camera A and Camera B take their last picture together, how many minutes before noon is it?
natural solution: If Camera A and Camera B take a picture at the same time, they will take a picture $77$ minutes later at the same time.

Therefore, if we can find the first time they take a picture together, then we can continue adding $77$ minutes to figure out when the fourth picture was taken. Camera A's first pictures after $7$ AM is at $7:06$, followed by $7:17$ and $7:28$.
Camera B will take a picture at $7:28$.
From here, we add $77$ minutes until we have taken four pictures. $7:28$ is followed by $8:45$, which is followed by $10:02$, which is followed by $11:19$. This is $\boxed{41}$ minutes before noon.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. t >= 0 \<longrightarrow> A t = 11 * t"
and h1 : "\<forall> t. t >= 0 \<longrightarrow> B t = 7 * t + 60"
and h2 : "\<exists> t. t >= 0 \<and> t < 240 \<and> A t = B t"
and h3 : "card {t. t >= 0 \<and> t < 240 \<and> A t = B t} = 4"
shows  "Max {t. t >= 0 \<and> t < 240 \<and> A t = B t} = 41"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 There are two cameras that take pictures of a traffic intersection. Camera A starts taking pictures at $6$ AM and takes a picture every $11$ minutes. Camera B starts taking pictures at $7$ AM and takes pictures every $7$ minutes. Camera A and Camera B take a picture at the same time at four different times before noon. When Camera A and Camera B take their last picture together, how many minutes before noon is it? The final Answer is 41
 ### Proof
 If Camera A and Camera B take a picture at the same time, they will take a picture $77$ minutes later at the same time.
 Therefore, if we can find the first time they take a picture together, then we can continue adding $77$ minutes to figure out when the fourth picture was taken. Camera A's first pictures after $7$ AM is at $7:06$, followed by $7:17$ and $7:28$.
 Camera B will take a picture at $7:28$.
 From here, we add $77$ minutes until we have taken four pictures. $7:28$ is followed by $8:45$, which is followed by $10:02$, which is followed by $11:19$. This is $\boxed{41}$ minutes before noon.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. t >= 0 \<longrightarrow> A t = 11 * t"
and h1 : "\<forall> t. t >= 0 \<longrightarrow> B t = 7 * t + 60"
and h2 : "\<exists> t. t >= 0 \<and> t < 240 \<and> A t = B t"
and h3 : "card {t. t >= 0 \<and> t < 240 \<and> A t = B t} = 4"
shows  "Max {t. t >= 0 \<and> t < 240 \<and> A t = B t} = 41"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Consider two functions, A and B, defined on non-negative integers as follows: $A(t) = 11t$ and $B(t) = 7t + 60$. We know there are four distinct non-negative integers less than 240 for which A and B yield the same value. What is the maximum of these four integers? The final answer is 41.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. t >= 0 \<longrightarrow> A t = 6 * 60 + 11 * t"
and h1 : "\<forall> t. t >= 0 \<longrightarrow> B t = 7 * 60 + 7 * t"
and h2 : "\<exists> t1 t2 t3 t4. t1 < t2 \<and> t2 < t3 \<and> t3 < t4 \<and> t4 < 12 * 60 \<and> A t1 = B t1 \<and> A t2 = B t2 \<and> A t3 = B t3 \<and> A t4 = B t4"
shows  "\<forall> t. t >= 0 \<longrightarrow> A t = B t \<longrightarrow> t <= 12 * 60 - 41"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 There are two cameras that take pictures of a traffic intersection. Camera A starts taking pictures at $6$ AM and takes a picture every $11$ minutes. Camera B starts taking pictures at $7$ AM and takes pictures every $7$ minutes. Camera A and Camera B take a picture at the same time at four different times before noon. When Camera A and Camera B take their last picture together, how many minutes before noon is it? The final Answer is 41
 ### Proof
 If Camera A and Camera B take a picture at the same time, they will take a picture $77$ minutes later at the same time.

 Camera B will take a picture at $7:28$.
 From here, we add $77$ minutes until we have taken four pictures. $7:28$ is followed by $8:45$, which is followed by $10:02$, which is followed by $11:19$. This is $\boxed{41}$ minutes before noon.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. t >= 0 \<longrightarrow> A t = 6 * 60 + 11 * t"
and h1 : "\<forall> t. t >= 0 \<longrightarrow> B t = 7 * 60 + 7 * t"
and h2 : "\<exists> t1 t2 t3 t4. t1 < t2 \<and> t2 < t3 \<and> t3 < t4 \<and> t4 < 12 * 60 \<and> A t1 = B t1 \<and> A t2 = B t2 \<and> A t3 = B t3 \<and> A t4 = B t4"
shows  "\<forall> t. t >= 0 \<longrightarrow> A t = B t \<longrightarrow> t <= 12 * 60 - 41"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem:
Two trains A and B start at the same time. Train A leaves at 6:00 AM and travels at a speed of 11 units per hour. Train B leaves at 7:00 AM and travels at a speed of 7 units per hour. 

There are four different times t1, t2, t3, t4 (with t1 < t2 < t3 < t4 and all are before 12:00 PM) such that the positions of the two trains are the same at these four times. 

Find the latest time before 12:00 PM when the positions of the two trains will be the same again. The final answer is 12:00 PM minus 41 minutes.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n > 0 \<longrightarrow> A n = 60 + 11 * n"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n > 0 \<longrightarrow> B n = 60 + 7 * n"
and h2 : "length (filter (\<lambda> n. A n = B n) [1..<720]) = 4"
shows  "last (filter (\<lambda> n. A n = B n) [1..<720]) = 41"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 There are two cameras that take pictures of a traffic intersection. Camera A starts taking pictures at $6$ AM and takes a picture every $11$ minutes. Camera B starts taking pictures at $7$ AM and takes pictures every $7$ minutes. Camera A and Camera B take a picture at the same time at four different times before noon.  Camera B will take a picture at $7:28$.
 From here, we add $77$ minutes until we have taken four pictures. $7:28$ is followed by $8:45$, which is followed by $10:02$, which is followed by $11:19$. This is $\boxed{41}$ minutes before noon.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n > 0 \<longrightarrow> A n = 60 + 11 * n"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n > 0 \<longrightarrow> B n = 60 + 7 * n"
and h2 : "length (filter (\<lambda> n. A n = B n) [1..<720]) = 4"
shows  "last (filter (\<lambda> n. A n = B n) [1..<720]) = 41"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Consider two functions $A$ and $B$ defined for all positive integers. Function $A$ is defined as $A(n) = 60 + 11n$, and function $B$ is defined as $B(n) = 60 + 7n$. If we list all numbers from 1 to 719 (inclusive) for which $A(n) = B(n)$, there are four such numbers. What is the largest of these four numbers? The final answer is 41.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "A 0 = 6 * 60"
and h1 : "B 0 = 7 * 60"
and h2 : "\<forall> n \<ge> 1. A n = A (n - 1) + 11"
and h3 : "\<forall> n \<ge> 1. B n = B (n - 1) + 7"
and h4 : "C 0 = A 0"
and h5 : "\<forall> n \<ge> 1. C n = A n = B n"
and h6 : "C 3 < 12 * 60"
and h7 : "C 4 > 12 * 60"
shows  "12 * 60 - C 3 = 41"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 There are two cameras that take pictures of a traffic intersection. Camera A starts taking pictures at $6$ AM and takes a picture every $11$ minutes. Camera B starts taking pictures at $7$ AM and takes pictures every $7$ minutes. Camera A and Camera B take a picture at the same time at four different times before noon. When Camera A and Camera B take their last picture together, how many minutes before noon is it? The final Answer is 41
 ### Proof
 If Camera A and Camera B take a picture at the same time, they will take a picture $77$ minutes later at the same time.
 Therefore, if we can find the first time they take a picture together, then we can continue adding $77$ minutes to figure out when the fourth picture was taken. Camera A's first pictures after $7$ AM is at $7:06$, followed by $7:17$ and $7:28$.
 Camera B will take a picture at $7:28$.
 From here, we add $77$ minutes until we have taken four pictures. $7:28$ is followed by $8:45$, which is followed by $10:02$, which is followed by $11:19$. This is $\boxed{41}$ minutes before noon.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "A 0 = 6 * 60"
and h1 : "B 0 = 7 * 60"
and h2 : "\<forall> n \<ge> 1. A n = A (n - 1) + 11"
and h3 : "\<forall> n \<ge> 1. B n = B (n - 1) + 7"
and h4 : "C 0 = A 0"
and h5 : "\<forall> n \<ge> 1. C n = A n = B n"
and h6 : "C 3 < 12 * 60"
and h7 : "C 4 > 12 * 60"
shows  "12 * 60 - C 3 = 41"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: A clock starts at 6:00 and moves forward by 11 minutes each hour. Another clock starts at 7:00 and moves forward by 7 minutes each hour. A third clock matches the time of the first clock and keeps synchronizing with the time of the fastest clock. If the third clock shows a time earlier than 12:00 at the third hour and later than 12:00 at the fourth hour, find the difference between 12:00 and the time displayed by the third clock at the third hour. The final answer is 41 minutes.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. A n = 60 + 11 * n"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. B n = 60 + 60 + 7 * n"
and h2 : "card {n. A n = B n \<and> A n < 12 * 60} = 4"
shows  "Max {n. A n = B n \<and> A n < 12 * 60} = 12 * 60 - 41"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 There are two cameras that take pictures of a traffic intersection. Camera A starts taking pictures at $6$ AM and takes a picture every $11$ minutes. Camera B starts taking pictures at $7$ AM and takes pictures every $7$ minutes. Camera A and Camera B take a picture at the same time at four different times before noon.  Camera B will take a picture at $7:28$.
 From here, we add $77$ minutes until we have taken four pictures. $7:28$ is followed by $8:45$, which is followed by $10:02$, which is followed by $11:19$. This is $\boxed{41}$ minutes before noon.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. A n = 60 + 11 * n"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. B n = 60 + 60 + 7 * n"
and h2 : "card {n. A n = B n \<and> A n < 12 * 60} = 4"
shows  "Max {n. A n = B n \<and> A n < 12 * 60} = 12 * 60 - 41"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Consider two sequences of natural numbers $A$ and $B$ where $A(n) = 60 + 11n$ and $B(n) = 120 + 7n$. Find the maximum number that appears in both sequences and is less than $12*60$. The answer should be $12*60 - 41$. Note that there are exactly 4 such numbers.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B :: "(nat \<Rightarrow> nat)"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. A n = 11 * n + 60"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. B n = 7 * n + 420"
and h2 : "\<exists>n. A n = B n \<and> B n \<le> 720"
and h3 : "\<forall>n. A n = B n \<longrightarrow> A (n+1) \<noteq> B (n+1)"
shows  "\<exists>n. A n = B n \<and> 720 - B n = 41"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 There are two cameras that take pictures of a traffic intersection. Camera A starts taking pictures at $6$ AM and takes a picture every $11$ minutes. Camera B starts taking pictures at $7$ AM and takes pictures every $7$ minutes. Camera A and Camera B take a picture at the same time at four different times before noon.  Camera B will take a picture at $7:28$.
 From here, we add $77$ minutes until we have taken four pictures. $7:28$ is followed by $8:45$, which is followed by $10:02$, which is followed by $11:19$. This is $\boxed{41}$ minutes before noon.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B :: "(nat \<Rightarrow> nat)"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. A n = 11 * n + 60"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. B n = 7 * n + 420"
and h2 : "\<exists>n. A n = B n \<and> B n \<le> 720"
and h3 : "\<forall>n. A n = B n \<longrightarrow> A (n+1) \<noteq> B (n+1)"
shows  "\<exists>n. A n = B n \<and> 720 - B n = 41"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Find a natural number $n$ such that $11n + 60 = 7n + 420$ and the difference between $720$ and $7n + 420$ equals $41$. Note that, if $11n + 60 = 7n + 420$ holds for a certain $n$, it does not hold for $n+1$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. A n = 6*60 + n*11"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. B n = 7*60 + n*7"
and h2 : "\<exists> n. A n = B n \<and> n < 12*60"
and h3 : "\<forall> n m. n < m \<longrightarrow> A n \<noteq> B m"
shows  "\<exists> n. A n = B n \<and> n = 12*60 - 41"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 There are two cameras that take pictures of a traffic intersection. Camera A starts taking pictures at $6$ AM and takes a picture every $11$ minutes.  From here, we add $77$ minutes until we have taken four pictures. $7:28$ is followed by $8:45$, which is followed by $10:02$, which is followed by $11:19$. This is $\boxed{41}$ minutes before noon.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. A n = 6*60 + n*11"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. B n = 7*60 + n*7"
and h2 : "\<exists> n. A n = B n \<and> n < 12*60"
and h3 : "\<forall> n m. n < m \<longrightarrow> A n \<noteq> B m"
shows  "\<exists> n. A n = B n \<and> n = 12*60 - 41"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Two events occur at a regular interval. The first event occurs every 6 hours and 11n minutes and the second event occurs every 7 hours and 7n minutes. It is known that there is an instance within a 12-hour period where both events occur at the same time and no later event coincides with any earlier one. Find the time instance within the 12-hour period, where both events occur simultaneously. The final answer is 41 minutes before the end of the 12-hour period.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. t \<ge> 0 \<longrightarrow> A(t) = 6 * 60 + t * 11"
and h1 : "\<forall> t. t \<ge> 0 \<longrightarrow> B(t) = 7 * 60 + t * 7"
and h2 : "card {t. t \<ge> 0 \<and> A(t) < 12 * 60 \<and> A(t) = B(t)} = 4"
shows  "Max {t. t \<ge> 0 \<and> A(t) < 12 * 60 \<and> A(t) = B(t)} = 12 * 60 - 41"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 There are two cameras that take pictures of a traffic intersection. Camera A starts taking pictures at $6$ AM and takes a picture every $11$ minutes. Camera B starts taking pictures at $7$ AM and takes pictures every $7$ minutes. Camera A and Camera B take a picture at the same time at four different times before noon.  ### Proof

 Camera B will take a picture at $7:28$.
 From here, we add $77$ minutes until we have taken four pictures. $7:28$ is followed by $8:45$, which is followed by $10:02$, which is followed by $11:19$. This is $\boxed{41}$ minutes before noon.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. t \<ge> 0 \<longrightarrow> A(t) = 6 * 60 + t * 11"
and h1 : "\<forall> t. t \<ge> 0 \<longrightarrow> B(t) = 7 * 60 + t * 7"
and h2 : "card {t. t \<ge> 0 \<and> A(t) < 12 * 60 \<and> A(t) = B(t)} = 4"
shows  "Max {t. t \<ge> 0 \<and> A(t) < 12 * 60 \<and> A(t) = B(t)} = 12 * 60 - 41"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem:
A and B are two functions of time (in minutes) defined as follows: 

A(t) = 6 * 60 + t * 11 for all t ≥ 0.
B(t) = 7 * 60 + t * 7 for all t ≥ 0.

Find the maximum value of t, such that A(t) equals B(t) and A(t) is less than 12 hours (or 720 minutes), given that there are exactly 4 such instances. The final answer is 719 minutes.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes Camera_A Camera_B :: "int => int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n >= 0 \<longrightarrow> Camera_A n = 6*60 + 11*n"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n >= 0 \<longrightarrow> Camera_B n = 7*60 + 7*n"
and h2 : "\<exists> n m. n >= 0 \<and> m >= 0 \<and> Camera_A n = Camera_B m \<and> Camera_A (n+1) > 12*60 \<and> Camera_B (m+1) > 12*60"
shows  "\<exists> n m. n >= 0 \<and> m >= 0 \<and> Camera_A n = Camera_B m \<and> Camera_A (n+1) > 12*60 \<and> Camera_B (m+1) > 12*60 \<and> 12*60 - Camera_A n = 41"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 There are two cameras that take pictures of a traffic intersection. Camera A starts taking pictures at $6$ AM and takes a picture every $11$ minutes. Camera B starts taking pictures at $7$ AM and takes pictures every $7$ minutes. Camera A and Camera B take a picture at the same time at four different times before noon. When Camera A and Camera B take their last picture together, how many minutes before noon is it? The final Answer is 41
 ### Proof
 If Camera A and Camera B take a picture at the same time, they will take a picture $77$ minutes later at the same time.
 Therefore, if we can find the first time they take a picture together, then we can continue adding $77$ minutes to figure out when the fourth picture was taken. Camera A's first pictures after $7$ AM is at $7:06$, followed by $7:17$ and $7:28$.
 Camera B will take a picture at $7:28$.
 From here, we add $77$ minutes until we have taken four pictures. $7:28$ is followed by $8:45$, which is followed by $10:02$, which is followed by $11:19$. This is $\boxed{41}$ minutes before noon.
 *)

theorem
fixes Camera_A Camera_B :: "int => int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n >= 0 \<longrightarrow> Camera_A n = 6*60 + 11*n"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n >= 0 \<longrightarrow> Camera_B n = 7*60 + 7*n"
and h2 : "\<exists> n m. n >= 0 \<and> m >= 0 \<and> Camera_A n = Camera_B m \<and> Camera_A (n+1) > 12*60 \<and> Camera_B (m+1) > 12*60"
shows  "\<exists> n m. n >= 0 \<and> m >= 0 \<and> Camera_A n = Camera_B m \<and> Camera_A (n+1) > 12*60 \<and> Camera_B (m+1) > 12*60 \<and> 12*60 - Camera_A n = 41"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Two cameras, Camera A and Camera B, start recording at different times. Camera A starts recording at 6:00 am and records an additional 11 minutes every hour. Camera B starts recording at 7:00 am and records an additional 7 minutes every hour. Find a time where both cameras have recorded the same amount of footage but the next minute they record will be past 12:00 pm. Additionally, there should be 41 minutes remaining until 12:00 pm from the time both cameras have recorded the same amount of footage.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes minutes_before_noon :: real
assumes h0 : "minutes_before_noon = 720 - (lcm (66, 60) * 4)"
shows  "minutes_before_noon = 41"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 There are two cameras that take pictures of a traffic intersection. Camera A starts taking pictures at $6$ AM and takes a picture every $11$ minutes. Camera B starts taking pictures at $7$ AM and takes pictures every $7$ minutes. Camera A and Camera B take a picture at the same time at four different times before noon. When Camera A and Camera B take their last picture together, how many minutes before noon is it? The final Answer is 41
 ### Proof
 If Camera A and Camera B take a picture at the same time, they will take a picture $77$ minutes later at the same time.
 Therefore, if we can find the first time they take a picture together, then we can continue adding $77$ minutes to figure out when the fourth picture was taken. Camera A's first pictures after $7$ AM is at $7:06$, followed by $7:17$ and $7:28$.
 Camera B will take a picture at $7:28$.
 From here, we add $77$ minutes until we have taken four pictures. $7:28$ is followed by $8:45$, which is followed by $10:02$, which is followed by $11:19$. This is $\boxed{41}$ minutes before noon.
 *)

theorem
fixes minutes_before_noon :: real
assumes h0 : "minutes_before_noon = 720 - (lcm (66, 60) * 4)"
shows  "minutes_before_noon = 41"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Find the number of minutes before noon, given that it is four times the least common multiple (LCM) of 66 and 60 subtracted from 720. The final answer is 41 minutes.
